botanical_details.potentially_harmful: Skin irritant. Wear gloves and other protective equipment when handling
botanical_details.genus: Hydrangea can be deciduous or evergreen shrubs, or self-clinging climbers, with flowers in clusters usually comprising both small fertile and more showy sterile flowers; often good autumn colour

how_to_grow.cultivation: Grow in moist but well-drained, humus rich soil. Provide shelter from cold, drying winds. See shrubby hydrangea cultivation for more detailed advice
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by softwood cuttings in early summer, or hardwood cuttings in winter
how_to_grow.pruning: Pruning group 1 or pruning group 6. Blooms on new wood, so can be cut back in autumn or spring. For larger flower heads, cut back previous season's growth to within a few buds of the woody framework in early spring
how_to_grow.pests: May be susceptible to aphids, scale insects, vine weevils and capsid bug
how_to_grow.diseases: May be susceptible to grey moulds, powdery mildews, leaf spot, honey fungus and virus diseases
